English
Government.

Question 1.Question: Which subject is this given to you?
Question 1.Explanation: This is Government.

Options.Value: Self -actualization
Liberation
Sovereignty
Nationalism

Question 2.Question: Nation-state is synonymous with
Question 2.Explanation: Nation-state is a feeling of patriotism and the idea of supporting one's country, people or culture regardless of diversity. This is also known as the spirit of nationalism.

Options.Value: Social values
Community structure
Family values
Economic values

Question 3.Question: A fundamental component of political culture is
Question 3.Explanation: Political culture consists of the values and norms which guide the political philosophy and behavior of any society or community.

Options.Value: Aristocracy
Plutocracy
Theocracy
Gerontocracy

Question 4.Question: A form of oligarchy in which gifted people are at the helm of affairs is
Question 4.Explanation: Plutocracy is the system of government under the control of the wealthy class; theocracy is a government headed by God represented by religious leaders while gerontocracy is a government that is controlled by the aged. In aristocracy, the highest class in certain societies, typically comprising people of noble birth holding hereditary titles and offices or with special gifts are the ones who rule.

Options.Value: A monarchy
A republic
A plutocracy
An empire

Question 5.Question: A state that is ruled by an elected citizen is
Question 5.Explanation: Monarchy is the system whereby the country is ruled by a monarch i.e. king or queen; plutocracy is a government which is led by the rich while an empire is a land under the control of an emperor i.e. ruler of a very vast area of land. A republic is a form of government in which the country is considered a "public matter", not the private concern or property of the rulers, considering they were elected by the people for a specified period of time.

Options.Value: Elected representative's rule
Majority of the people vote
Majority of the people rule
Elite rules

Question 6.Question: A true democracy in the modern sense exists where the
Question 6.Explanation: Majority of the people of a country can only rule through their representatives who are elected by a vote of the majority.

Options.Value: Executive is expected to go on suspension
Executive is required to resign
Legislature ceases to trust the executive
Legislature commences legal proceeding against the executive

Question 7.Question: In a parliamentary system, when the legislature passes a vote of no confidence on the executive, it means that the
Question 7.Explanation: A vote of no confidence means the legislative has withdrawn its support for the executive without which the government cannot survive as no bill presented by the executive to the parliament can sail through. Usually, such executive committee has to resign.

Options.Value: Parliament
Congress
National assembly
Council

Question 8.Question: The legislative body of the United States of America is the
Question 8.Explanation: The Parliament is the legislature of the United Kingdom; the National Assembly is the legislature of Nigeria; and in the United States, it is called the Congress. It is made up of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

Options.Value: Israel
The United Kingdom
The United States
Ghana

Question 9.Question: Uni-cameralism is a feature of the legislature in
Question 9.Explanation: Other countries in the options operate bicameralism. The legislature of Ghana is officially known as the Parliament of Ghana.

Options.Value: Ensure equality of federating units
Oversee and check the lower house
Prevent excesses of the executive
Enable experienced elders make inputs to governance

Question 10.Question: The upper house in most federal systems is created to
Question 10.Explanation: Federal states all have heterogeneous population. The upper house is therefore necessary to reduce fears of domination by certain ethnic groups over others.

Options.Value: Monarchical
Unitary
Federal
Confederal

Question 11.Question: In which of the following systems is the power of the component units more than that of the central government?
Question 11.Explanation: In a federal setup, the government at the centre possesses greater powers than the component units. In a unitary state, the component states can only assist the centre to execute its functions as they have no power of their own. In a confederal setup, the component units have the power so the central government is weak and has less power.

Options.Value: Supreme relative to the constitution
Subordinate to the laws of the state
Weak relative to the constitution
Subordinate to the norms of the society

Question 12.Question: One of the general tenets of fascist doctrine is that leader is
Question 12.Explanation: In fascism, the leader is regarded as the repository of wisdom and so is above the constitution and other citizens of the state.

Options.Value: Head of government
President
Monarch
Dominant party

Question 13.Question: In a cabinet system of government, executive power is exercised by the
Question 13.Explanation: The head of government exercises the executive power. Though the dominant party may produce the head of government, the executive power is not vested in it.

Options.Value: Presidential system
Monarchical system
Parliamentary system
Feudal system

Question 14.Question: The principle of separation of powers is best practiced in the
Question 14.Explanation: Separation of powers means that functions of the executive, legislature and judiciary are not carried out exclusively by one arm of the government. It is best practiced in the Presidential system of government.

Options.Value: An act
A decree
A bill
A bye -law

Question 15.Question: A typical form of delegated legislation is
Question 15.Explanation: In short, delegated legislation means the exercise of legislative power by an agency which is not the legislature. Acts and decrees are enacted by legislative bodies. On the other hand, a bye-law is a law made by local governments, government parastatals or companies. It is therefore a form of delegated legislation.

Options.Value: Opposes the government violently
Is convicted of a serious crime
Leaves the country permanently
Is pronounced dead

Question 16.Question: The rights of a citizen can be withdrawn by the state if the person
Question 16.Explanation: Upon conviction of a crime, a citizen by naturalization can lose his citizenship

Options.Value: Primary election
Bye election
Electoral College
General election

Question 17.Question: An electoral process in which candidates are selected for elective offices by party members is
Question 17.Explanation: Primary elections or often just primaries are the process by which members of a party choose the candidate who will represent the party in the general election. A bye-election is one that is held to fill an elective position that becomes vacant before the expiration of the term. An electoral college is a system in which a group of people are chosen to select leaders while a general election is that which allows all qualified people (usually adults above a certain age) to vote for leaders of their choice.

Options.Value: Eliminates intra-party conflict
Promotes greater mass participation in government
Serves as an instrument of national integration
Guarantees social justice

Question 18.Question: In theory, one major advantage of the one-party system is that it
Question 18.Explanation: Another advantage of a one-party system is that the entire nation is able to rally round the only party regardless of their ethnic, religious and cultural differences. In other words, one-party system promotes unity and national integration.

Options.Value: Memorandum
Propaganda
Electioneering campaign
Lobbying

Question 19.Question: A tactic employed by pressure groups to achieve their objectives is
Question 19.Explanation: Lobbying involves seeking to influence the legislature on an issue. Pressure groups use this method. Political parties employ electioneering campaign and propaganda in their attempt to gain political power.

Options.Value: Negotiation
Strike action
Referendum
Rumor

Question 20.Question: Public opinion can be measured through
Question 20.Explanation: A Referendum is a general vote by the electorate on a single political question which has been referred to them for a direct decision.

Options.Value: Implementing government policies
Supporting the party in power
Allocating resources to the federating units
Mobilizing grassroot support for government

Question 21.Question: Which of the following is the main function of the civil service?
Question 21.Explanation: Other functions of the civil service are policy formation, giving advice to the government, preparation and execution of annual budget and documentation of government activities.

Options.Value: Bashorun
Aremo
Oyomesi
Alaafin

Question 22.Question: Who was the political head of the old Oyo Empire?
Question 22.Explanation: The Bashorun was the Prime Minister; Oyomesi was the seven-panel of king maker chiefs while the Aremo was the heir-apparent.

Options.Value: Age grades
Family ties
Umunna
Umuada

Question 23.Question: The Igbo political system was based on
Question 23.Explanation: The Igbo village assembly was made up of related families and decisions reached during meetings of the village assembly were enforced by the age grades which served as the police force.

Options.Value: A religious organization
A commercial organization
A political organization
An imperial organization

Question 24.Question: The Aro age-grade system in Igbo land was
Question 24.Explanation: The Aro age-grade system in pre-colonial Igbo land was a political organization which was responsible for running the affairs of the society.

Options.Value: Teach them the art of leadership
Change their way of life
Give them a sound education
Discourage them from ritual killings

Question 25.Question: France introduced the policy of assimilation in her colonies primarily to
Question 25.Explanation: Assimilation was one ideological basis of French colonial policy in the 19th and 20th centuries. In contrast with British imperial policy, the French taught their subjects that, by adopting French language and culture, they could eventually become French.

Options.Value: Royal Niger Company
Lever Brothers
United African Company
John Holt and sons

Question 26.Question: The foremost British trading company on West African coast was
Question 26.Explanation: The Royal Niger Company was a mercantile company chartered by the British government in the nineteenth century. It was formed in 1879 as the United African Company and renamed to National African Company in 1881 and to Royal Niger Company in 1886.

Options.Value: King Kosoko
Oba Ovoranwen
King Dosunmu
King Jaja

Question 27.Question: Which of these rulers resisted colonial rule and was deported to Calabar?
Question 27.Explanation: Oba Ovonramwen of Benin was exiled to Calabar by the British, with two of his wives, Queen Egbe and Queen Aighobahi, where he died in the year 1914. King Jaja of Opobo was exiled to St. Vincents Island in the West Indies.

Options.Value: John Payne Jackson
James. S. Coleman
Edward Wilmot Blyden
David Ricardo

Question 28.Question: Nigerian nationalism was described as two – phased by
Question 28.Explanation: Edward Wilmot Blyden was an educator, writer, diplomat, and politician primarily in Liberia. He taught for five years in the British West African Colony of Sierra Leone in the early 20th century. His wrote on pan-Africanism.

Options.Value: Failed to provide the country with full sovereignty
Gave full powers to the Supreme Court in Nigeria
Gave total independence to Nigeria
Empowered Britain to continue to rule

Question 29.Question: One major weakness of the independence constitution is that it
Question 29.Explanation: The Independence Constitution still had the Queen of England as the Monarch and head of state.

Options.Value: Nigeria council
Legislative council
National Assembly
Regional Assembly

Question 30.Question: The first law-making body in Nigeria after amalgamation was
Question 30.Explanation: The Legislative Council was established by the 1922 Clifford's Constitution while the Richard's constitution of 1946 set up regional assemblies. The Independence Constitution of 1960 provided for the National Assembly.

Simeon Adebo
S. J. Cookey
Dotun Philips

Question 31.Question: The designation of ministers as chief executives and accounting officers was recommended by a commission headed by
Question 31.Explanation: Jerome Udoji headed the commission that reviewed the salaries and allowances of workers in 1974. Simeon Adebo was for many years Nigeria's Permanent Representative at the United Nations while S. J. Cookey was the Chairman of the 1986 Political Bureau that fashioned out Babangida's Transition to Civil Rule Programme.

Options.Value: Lack of adequate resources
Its inability to restrain bureaucratic excesses
Lack of clear-cut mandate
Lack of executive power to enforce decisions

Question 32.Question: A major shortcoming of the Ombudsman is
Question 32.Explanation: In Nigeria the ombudsman is known as the Public Complaints Commission, the machinery for the control of administrative excesses or injustices at federal, state and local government levels, as well as private corporations.

Options.Value: The provision for a bicameral legislature
Government interference
Wider political participation
Wider anti-democracy camp

Question 33.Question: One of the strong points of the multi-party system in Nigeria's Fourth Republic is
Question 33.Explanation: Nigeria currently has a total of 54 registered political parties giving the citizenry a wide horizon of political self-actualization.

Options.Value: Presidential system of government
Federal system of government
Parliamentary system of government
Unitary system of government

Question 34.Question: In which of the following is ceremonial and executive powers fused?
Question 34.Explanation: Ceremonial and executive functions are separated and performed by two distinct persons under the parliamentary system. In a parliamentary state, the Head of state has executive powers and is also the president.

Options.Value: Poverty
Health care delivery
Education
Revenue allocation

Question 35.Question: A major contentious issue confronting Nigerian federalism is
Question 35.Explanation: Revenue allocation can be described as a method of sharing the centrally generated revenue among different tiers of government and how the amount allocated to a particular tier is shared among its components for economic development.

Options.Value: Increase government revenue
Enrich the elite
Provide essential services
Compete with the private sector

Question 36.Question: The main purpose of establishing public enterprises in Nigeria is to
Question 36.Explanation: Public corporations are established to provide essential services to the citizens such as water, electricity and good roads at a cheap rate that can be afforded by the citizens.

Options.Value: Enhance entrepreneurial skills
Expand business transactions
Maximize government profits
Render social services

Question 37.Question: Parasatals are established to
Question 37.Explanation: Examples of parastatals are the NNPC, NTA, PHCN, NBS and NPA.

Body responsible for supervising self-help projects
Local government public relations unit

Question 38.Question: The General Purpose Committee of the local government is the
Question 38.Explanation: The General Purpose Committee is made up of the Chairman, Vice Chairman and Heads of Departments.

Options.Value: Provisional Ruling Council
Armed Forces Ruling Council
Supreme Military Council

Question 39.Question: The highest organ of the state during the Babangida Regime was the
Question 39.Explanation: The Provisional Ruling Council was in operation under the Abacha government; the Supreme Military Council was under the regimes of Ironsi, Gowon, Murtala/Obasanjo and Buhari/Idiagbon; the Armed Forces Ruling council was under Babangida while the Federal Executive Council was the national executive body under civilian regimes.

Promulgated without consultation with the people
Perceived to abolish the federal system
Considered as alien

Question 40.Question: Decree 34 of 1966 was unacceptable to many Nigerians because it was
Question 40.Explanation: It was promulgated on May 24, 1966 by then Head of State, Major General Thomas Aguiyi Ironsi. It was called the Unification Decree which changed Nigeria from a federation to a unitary state.

Her poor relations with the francophone countries
General de-Gaulle's negative attitude towards her
France's diplomatic relations with Israel

Question 41.Question: Nigeria broke diplomatic relations with France in 1961 because of
Question 41.Explanation: France conducted its first nuclear bomb test at Reganne, Algeria, in the Sahara desert. The breaking of ties with France because of this act was a demonstration of Nigeria's adoption of Africa as centre piece of her foreign policy since independence in 1960.

Options.Value: The state of her economy
Her large population
Her heterogeneous population
Her large size

Question 42.Question: An attribute that Nigeria shares with most non-aligned countries is
Question 42.Explanation: The Non-Aligned movement has member countries which are mostly third-world or underdeveloped countries.

Question 43.Explanation: ECOWAS was formed in May 1975 two months before Gowon's military regime was toppled in a bloodless coup and succeeded by the Murtala Muhammed/Obasanjo Junta.

Question 44.Explanation: The Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group (ECOMOG) was a West African multilateral armed force established by the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) to help end the crisis in Liberia. Nigeria played a dominant role.

Question 45.Explanation: Nigeria's prominent role in world affairs in the 70s was largely due to her increasing wealth from oil reserves and her victory in the civil war.

Question 46.Question: The head of Nigeria's foreign mission in a commonwealth nation is known as
Question 46.Explanation: The head of the country's foreign mission in a non-commonwealth country is known as the ambassador. The Charge d' affaires and the Attaché are officials in the embassy under the high commissioner/ambassador.

Question 47.Question: One major function of the Authority of Heads of State and Government of ECOWAS is
Question 47.Explanation: The budget is prepared by the Council of ministers; the appointment of the staff of the secretariat and organization of international conferences are the duties of the Executive Secretary.

Question 48.Question: The tenure of non-permanent members of the Security Council is
Question 48.Explanation: To be elected as a non-permanent member of the Security Council, each member country requires a vote of two-third majority of the entire assembly.

Permanent members of the Security Council on the recommendation of the General Assembly

Question 49.Explanation: The Secretary-General's appointment is subject to the veto of any of the five permanent members of the Security Council.

Question 50.Question: The approval of treaties and agreements of the Economic Community of West African states is the responsibility of the
Question 50.Explanation: The Assembly of Heads of State and Government is the highest organ of the organization. It is responsible for key appointments and admission of new members into the organization.
